newsitem.title: USA: Atmel rises on a short squeeze - CFO.
newsitem.headline: Atmel rises on a short squeeze - CFO.

text.p: Shares of Atmel Corp rebounded on Friday in heavy trading as investors scurried to cover short positions, Chief Financial Officer Kris Chellam told Reuters.

"People put out negative information yesterday that I was going to downgrade (my earnings estimates for) the next two quarters and as the facts got out and people really understood what I said we got some buyers coming in," Chellam said.
He said the stock fell 2 to 24-7/8 Thursday as Wall Street short players misinterpreted comments he made at a luncheon.

On Friday, Amtel topped the most active list on Nasdaq with shares climbing 1-3/4 to 26-5/8 on volume of over seven million shares as it became clear Chellam's remarks were not as negative as some initially thought.

"At the luncheon, unfortunately, there was some short interest players in the room and they took some of the comments I made and turned it into negative. It was a misunderstanding of what I said," Chellam said.
"The only comment I made is that the visibility in the industry has changed, it's no different for us," he added.
Chellam told analysts visibility, meaning how far in advance Atmel customers book orders, had dropped dramatically from the traditional three to six month period.

"Some people asked some hypothetical questions and I gave some hypothetical answers and some of them turned that around and implied that I said the company's gross margins were about to go down in Q4. I never actually said that," he said.
Chellam declined to comment on whether he is comfortable with analysts' earnings estimates but said Friday he did not feel the need to give analysts any "guidance" at this time.
"If we felt for any reason that we had concerns with meeting numbers we would make a press release," he said.

Chellam did say that orders in the third quarter were slow and that in a reduced visbility market it was hard to predict how the company would fare in the fourth quarter which is when Atmel does 80 percent of its business.

"Third quarter business is proceeding pretty fairly. Eighty percent of my end market is seasonally in the December quarter because of Christmas," he said. "There's no reason to believe that even though bookings may be seasonally slow there won't be an upturn in business in Q4 to grow the numbers."
That lower visibility caused Needham & Co on Friday to cut its recommendation on the stock to buy from strong buy.

"Needham basically downgraded the stock only because they felt that with limited visibility Atmel could not consistently beat estimates going forward," Chellam said. "I didn't say for a fact that we could or could not exceed estimates, it was just an estimate that they made based on reduced visibility."
Chellam said he did see signs of hope for the fourth quarter with a pick-up of activity particularly in the consumer market and the telecom sector.
"We've seen some signs of pickup in the U.S marketplace," he said.
Analysts agreed with Chellam's prognosis, noting that Atmel has a heavy short position
"Some of the things he said were taken in the wrong context," said Justin Burgin, analyst at Olde Discount Corp.

"There's a lot of shares short, close to 10 million shares short, and there's only 100 million shares outstanding, so that's a pretty good chunk and you may be getting a short squeeze," Burgin said. "Atmel has yet to disappoint in this entire chip downturn."
San Jose-based Atmel makes a broad range of integrated circuits.
